text.p: Prudential Insurance Co. of America said it agreed to pay at least $410 million to settle lawsuits by policyholders claiming they were victims of deceptive sales practices.
Under the settlement, about 10.7 million policyholders who bought permanent life insurance policies between 1982 and 1995 would be eligible to apply for restitution.

The settlement improves the terms of an agreement Prudential reached with a multi-state task force of insurance regulators this summer, said Melvyn Weiss, one of the lead attorneys negotiating the settlement.

It provides policyholders with the potential for greater relief and makes it easier for them to qualify for it, he said. Weiss expects the policyholders to enter into a formal agreement with Prudential on Oct. 25 and a notice to class members to be sent out in November.
"We believe the amounts paid out under our plan are more than what would have been paid out under the original plan," Weiss said.
A court hearing to determine whether or not the settlement is fair is likely to be held sometime in February or March.
"This settlement allows Prudential to move forward in providing the best possible service to our clients and customers" said Prudential Chairman Arthur Ryan

The settlement marks Prudential's latest effort to resolve allegations that it improperly pressured unsophisticated investors to replace their life insurance policies, a practice known as churning or twisting.
In July, insurance regulators from 43 states and Washington, D.C., recommended a $35 million fine and restitution programme for sales abuses by Prudential.
Prudential said it will request that the remediation programmes previously accepted by the states be modified to make them consistent with the class action settlement.
Prudential said discussions are being held with the remaining seven states to acquaint them with the terms of the class action settlement.
Those states had opposed the original multi-state agreement because of concern that it placed the burden of proof of wrongdoing on policyholders and not the company.
Complaints about abusive sales practices have plagued the life insurance industry over the past few years.
Metropolitan Life Insurance Co., New York Life Insurance Co. and Allianz Life Insurance Co. of North America all have been involved in similar actions in the last two years.

Metropolitan Life agreed in 1994 to pay $20 million in fines and up to $76 million in policyholder refunds to settle allegations it improperly marketed life insurance policies as retirement or savings plans.

New York Life last year agreed to a national class action settlement in a dispute over dividends on life insurance policies and Allianz Life in June agreed to pay $5.1 million, including $2.3 million in restitution to settle allegations it engaged in deceptive sales practices in California.

New York insurance regulators earlier this month moved to fight the industry's problems by proposing a tough new regulation to protect consumers from the inappropriate replacement of life insurance policies.
The Prudential class action settlement includes general relief as well as an alternative dispute resolution process.
The general relief, which includes enhanced life insurance, annuities and low-cost premium loans, is available to all policyholders who purchased permanent life insurance policies from 1982 to 1995.
Prudential said it did not have an estimate of the value of the general relief to policyholders.
Under the alternative dispute resolution process, policyholders could be eligible for restitution, as well as additional compensation, Prudential said.
The amount Prudential will pay under the alternative dispute resolution process is not capped, but the insurer is committed to paying at least $410 million.
If Prudential receives more than 110,000 legitimate claims, then it will pay out more than $410 million.

Under a formula worked out in the settlement, if Prudential receives 330,000 legitimate claims, it would pay $780 million in restitution and $300 million in additional compensation for a total payout of about $1.08 billion.
